job_title: Registered Nurse NICU in Bend, OR
pros: Pay is very good and is available online by searching for the ONA contract for this hospital. NICU coworkers are like a family and really work together. Management always has its issues everywhere you go, but this hospital has the best management I have worked under. Manager rounds every morning to ask if anything is needed or if we have any concerns. Ratios are great!
cons: Management turnover seems to be very high, you have to float to either PP or Peds in rotation (not that bad), census can be low most of the time so being floated or called off will happen during these times. Overall, not many cons to working here!

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist II in Redmond, OR

review_title: Laboratory System at St. Charles Hospital
pros: -good at getting your vacation requests approved
cons: -bad pay, bad management, bad hours

pros: My boss Maggie Arnold Rabine head of cardiovascular services was wonderful and very supportive. She always worked hard to give opportunities to train and work in other avenues if desired.
cons: It is nearly impossible to advance at St Charles. St Charles knows Bend is a desirable place to live so they don't bother to invest in their employees. Some hospitals would rather retain a hard working employee of five years and train them in a job. St Charles would rather hire someone out of state or out the area with prior experience than train employees. If even these employee have worked hard to finish a school program or degree. This happened to myself and several other employees that were friends and coworkers had to leave to a different hospital after finishing in school. It breeds a lot of resentment and unhappiness to know there's no opportunity for advancement.

review_title: They used to care for employees, not it is the bottom line.
pros:
They have been written up in several magazines for innovation.
Diverse job roles.
Largest employer in Central Oregon.
As the realtors say, location location location.
Good pay depending on your job.
Most of the doctors are great to work with.
cons:
Understaffed in the wrong areas.
Diverse job roles because you usually are doing the work of 2-3 people.
They hire based on degrees. A lot of employees with masters degrees but no real skills.
No moving up unless you know the right people. I cannot overstate this enough.
Most manager WILL NOT rock the boat. They are too worried about their own jobs.
You never know what direction the company is going to go and who is going to be let go because of it.
The reason I would not recommend to a friend is because jobs are being cut all the time. Doesn't matter who you are or how competent you are in your job. If the upper management has to make cuts, they make sure to keep their friends.
Most nurses are burnt out at the end of a 12-hour shift.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Bend, OR
pros: A paycheck, living in Central Oregon
cons: Management rules by intimidation and manipulation techniques. “Do as I say, not as I do” approach when Managers don’t even know what job their employees do. They have no idea what they even hire people for under them and expect current employees to train them. New management changes scheduled work days and hours without consideration for the current employees or departmental needs. Workers are under paid and receive no compensation close to their worth or ability. Competent employees are fired for standing up for themselves while ignorant, unskilled employees remain and allow themselves to be herded like cattle and trained as circus monkeys because they won’t “rock the boat” or question the management’s tactics. Applicants with experience receive base compensation and unskilled, inexperienced applicants are offered higher compensation for lower competence but higher ability to be manipulated. Expected behavior and performance is instilled by threat of job security, demotion, manipulation, intimidation, degradation, and insult. HR, UNUM and CAP support management and not employees rights or consideration.

job_title: Supervisor, Supply Chain Logistics and Distribution in Bend, OR
pros: It's rewarding to work in healthcare, and St. Charles is one of the better employers in central Oregon.  Most employees are good people.
cons: St. Charles is struggling with how to manage itself, and senior management often makes decisions that are not supported by sound logic and collaboration.  They made an attempt to acknowledge this by hiring a process improvement consultant, and measuring employee engagement.  However, both of those efforts have fallen short in showing sincere respect for those doing the work.  At first sign of declining engagement scores, St. Charles abandoned that program.  Many employees saw this as a betrayal of their commitment to the workforce.

review_title: Fighting through all the politics takes 50% of everyones energy
pros: fair pay decent benefits.  A lot of room (too much really) for upward mobility  There are MANY nice people!
cons: WAY, WAY too much politics!!!!  CYA is a constant battle.  The culture is "keep everybody in check so they don't make mistakes rather than equip them so there's fewer chances of mistakes.  A huge waste of human potential lost to CYA and politics.  50% of our time (at a minimum) lost, that could be for the better of all.

pros:
Great work location in a good community.
Opportunities to positively impact patient lives still exist.
Many frontline staff genuinely have patient care in focus.
cons:
Management is often absent and or unqualified.
Employees are being fired, bought out, and simply just walking away.
Poor communication within departments and between facilities.
Bad personal remain while skilled workers come and go.
Department wide resistance to innovation, accountability, and knowledge sharing.

review_title: HR is not for the employee, it’s for the employer
pros: Not really a whole lot of pros; just one really. My boss is amazing and works with whenever I need some extra help with work. She is the kind of boss who wants to build a connection and she does that.
cons: They do not give cost of loving raises as much as they should. Living in and paying for an apartment in Bend is impossible on what I make and it shouldn’t be that way. They also complain about not having enough money to give their hard working employees raises and yet they go around hiring ‘Big Wigs’ that they don’t need (at $250,000 per year!!!). They also consider continually spend money on new furniture, TVs, and things the hospital could do without. I work in a hospital where they pay me less than the average person in the same position in Bend. I work my butt off and yet someone else in my department, who has less experience than me, gets paid more than me! What is that?!

pros: I love the Nurses and CNAs I work with.  There is more flexibility working as an administrative person in the hospital setting and you are able to work with intelligent, clinically-minded people who really want to care for those who aren't well and want to make the world a better place once patient at a time.
cons: Personally, I had to make the very difficult decision to leave this position after 10 years in a town where jobs are extremely scarce. After years of being an administrative assistant I was given the title of Department Coordinator along with more responsibility and many more duties (as to be expected with this kind of change.)  What wasn't expected was an absolute 0 salary adjustment to go with that title and added job increase.  When questioning my Manager about it I was told they just didn't have any more money in the budget to add to my position and that I needed to do the best I could with the added responsibilities.  After years of working beyond what I can with this job and really, no value or appreciation and little recognition despite stellar annual evaluations, I feel the only action I can do is to leave.  I am overly sad by this and will miss all of my co-workers.  I feel there is something inherently wrong with an organization and especially a department like mine (we've lost 25% of our employees this year) when good employees leave like this.  I don't want to leave, but sometimes and in this case, actions are louder than words.  I hope care continues to be good at St.Charles Bend, but I may not be able to stay to find out as the job market in this town beyond the hospital is so grim.

review_title: Great people, company not so much.
pros: Your coworkers seem to care about their job.  I had probably the best manager of any job I have had, which made a huge difference in the experience.
cons: The company suffers from upper management groupthink.  Decisions take forever to be made and trickle down, which leads to "solutions" well after the fact.

pros: Central Oregon is a wonderful place to live! Tons of goings on downtown every weekend in the summer. Schedule of 7 - 3:30 is great.
cons: Process takes precedence. With a salary position overtime is an expectation. Current organizational changes make for a highly stressful work environment.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Bend, OR
pros: Good food at the hospital, beautiful interiors and artwork, friendly staff.
cons: Horrible management, quality of IT is trash (they have no idea how to fix technical problems at all), was degraded and reprimanded by my supervisor for the very thing she hired me for (my experiences another clinic with epic and feedback on improvement), lots of avoidable mistakes. There’s not a lot of good things to say.
